The discovery of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides and nitrides (MXenes) in 2011 has expanded the pool of nanomaterials available for a variety of applications. Characteristic properties of MXenes, such as high conductivity, hydrophilicity, and catalytic activity have led to a growing research interest for their use in environmental remediation and water treatment applications. This review summarizes recent advances in the synthesis and applications of MXenes as adsorbents, desalination membranes, electrodes for electrochemical deionization, and catalytic or antibacterial agents for water purification and other environmental remediation processes. The overview also features discussions on the computational attempts, biocompatibility, and environmental impact in the exploration of MXenes for water applications, highlighting the challenges and opportunities of these advanced 2D materials.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
The vast expansion of urban areas along with a rising global population are driving factors for the need to secure adequate and potable water [1]. Additionally, the rapid pace of industrialization has resulted in the production of hazardous waste that has negative impacts on health and the environment [2]. Presence of pollutants like heavy metals, salts, pharmaceuticals, aromatic compounds and textile dyes in water/wastewater streams pose a global environmental challenge because a majority of them are toxic and particularly threatening for living organisms [3–5]. Several biological and physiochemical methods such as aerobic/anaerobic digestion, biochar treatment [6–9], membrane filtration [10] and adsorption [11] have been conventionally implemented for removal of various environmental pollutants. Furthermore, nanomaterials are becoming an economically viable and environmentally friendly option for efficient environmental remediation as adsorbents, catalytic and antibacterial agents, and functional membranes for water/wastewater treat-

Engineering functional nanomaterial-based devices can allow us to achieve a new level of sensitivity, selectivity, efficiency, and mechanical stability for environmental remediation applications [14–15].
Two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials possess atomically thin structures with lateral sizes between tens of nanometers to a few micrometers. The large lateral size and nanometer thickness endow 2D nanomaterials with a high specific surface area, making them desirable in a plethora of environmental remediation applications, such as adsorption, sensing, and catalysis [16–17]. In the environmental remediation arena, graphene-based materials have demonstrated great success as sorbents, membrane separation, photocatalytic materials for waste decontamination, or as sensing materials for contaminant monitoring and/or removal [18–21]. Additionally, graphene and graphene oxide (GO) derivatives have demonstrated exceptional performance as water purification membranes with unique properties, such as ultrahigh water flux, selective molecular and ion sieving, as well as strong resistance to biofouling [15,22]. MXenes are a new class of 2D nanomaterials that have emerged from a large family of transition metal carbides, nitrides and carbonitrides denoted by the general formula Mn+1XnTx (n = 1–3), where M is an early transition metal group, X is carbon and/or nitrogen, and Tx are surface terminal groups (–OH, –O–, and/or –F) [28]. To date, close to 30 MXenes have been successfully synthesized including Ti3C2Tx, Ti2CTx, Nb4C3Tx [29] Ti3CNTx, Ta4C3Tx [30], Nb2CTx, V2CTx [31], Nb4C3Tx [29]; however, many more have been theoretically predicted based on the available MAX phase precursors [31–33]. Of those, titanium-based MXenes, such as Ti2CTx, and Ti3C2Tx are most promising for environmental applications due to element abundance and non-toxic decomposition products. Particularly, titanium carbide (Ti3C2Tx) is the most widely studied MXene [34]. Furthermore, different MXene compositions have been introduced with two or more transition metals in the M layers in both ordered and disordered structures (Mo2Ti2C3, (Ti0.5,Nb0.5)2C, (V0.5,Cr0.5)3C2) [35–39]. In addition to carbides, nitride and carbonitride MXenes have also been explored in few studies for electrochemical energy storage [40–42] and biomedical applications [43] and there have been several predictions of their properties. However, it remains intriguingly challenging to produce nitride MXenes by selective acid etching methods. The only exception is titanium carbonitride Ti3CN, which has been studied for several applications [44]. This is believed to be the main limiting factor for wide exploration of nitride and carbonitride MXenes in the environmental remediation applications.
MXenes have aroused intense interest for broadening their applications for environmental remediation due to their hydrophilicity, high surface area, activated metallic hydroxide sites, and environmentally friendly characteristics [45–49]. Pristine MXenes have a rare combination of metallic electronic conductivity and hydrophilicity, due to high electron density and surface functionality, respectively. In addition, these characteristic “conductive clay-like” properties of MXenes allow them to be easily processed by various methods, including spray coating, filtration, and painting, to design functional devices [35]. Furthermore, MXene-polymer and MXene-graphene composites have been developed to improve the performance of the pristine components such as reducing agglomeration, providing conductive pathways, and improving overall stability [50]. MXenes and their composites have had high impact in the energy storage [35,47,50] and biomedical fields [43]. Other emerging applications for MXenes include transparent conducting electrodes [51], electromagnetic interference shielding [52], reinforcements for composites [53], photo-, electro- and chemical catalysis [54– 56], and gas- and biosensors [47,57]. Moreover, MXenes are among very few 2D materials that can be produced in 100 g quantities per batch (even in research laboratories) by wet chemical synthesis. As previously mentioned, MXenes are made of non-toxic and abundant elements, such as Ti and C or N; therefore, their environmental degradation leads to carbon dioxide (CO2), nitrogen gas (N2) and Ti, which are non-toxic byproducts. This article provides an overview of MXenes’ potential for aqueous media applications including water purification membranes [56,58], heavy metal removal [59–60], capacitive deionization [61], and antimicrobial applications [62]. Since the vast majority of experimental studies in this field have been conducted on carbide MXenes with a limited exploration into nitrides and/or carbonitrides in this field [43], we are directing our review to this subgroup of the MXene family. The main concerns and mitigation strategies related to MXenes stability in the ambient, as well as bactericidal properties, toxicity, and environmental impact of MXenes will be evaluated in order to realize the full potential of MXene-based materials in various environmental systems.

sections.heading: Synthesis and characterizations
sections.text:
MXenes are generally prepared by selective etching of group A elements (Al or Si) from their MAX phase precursors [32]. Ti3AlC2 is the most common MAX phase precursor used for the preparation of Ti3C2Tx MXene. However, few etching routes have been systematically employed for the synthesis of MXenes [63–64]. The most common ways to selectively etch the Al layers from Ti3AlC2, where the previously existing Al layers are replaced with surface terminations (Tx) such as –F, –OH, –O–, are by direct use of hydrogen fluoride (HF) solution or in situ HF formed by reaction of hydrochloric acid (HCl) and a fluoride salt (such as lithium fluoride (LiF)) [34,65]. In both cases, the formed multilayered (ML) Ti3C2Tx (ML-MXene) can be treated by intercalation of water, cations, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH) and so on into the interlayer spacing to expand the layers of the ML-MXene, held weakly together by Van der Waals forces. Subsequent sonication can mechanically separate the layers to form delaminated (DL) Ti3C2Tx (DLMXene) suspensions, (Fig. 1(a)). However, MXene synthesis via the direct HF method involves multiple hazards related to HF use and handling [34–35,63,66]. Noticeably, the synthesis of stable Tin+1NnTx MXene by etching the Al from Tin+1AlNn with HF solutions at room temperature remains hitherto elusive. Other etchants have been explored [67] and the synthesis of 2D carbides and nitrides with MXene-like structures by salt templating [68] and gas phase processes are also being studied [69]. A schematic demonstrating the structure and synthesis routes of MXenes at room temperature, using direct HF or in situ HF, as well as various delamination pathways of ML-MXene is shown in Fig. 1(b). Etching of Al layers by direct HF method depends upon both the concentration of HF and reaction time [70–73]. Different stacking arrangements are observed for MXene flakes produced by the two methods. For example, after direct etching of Al layer using ( 30%) HF, the compact morphology of Ti3AlC2 is changed to loosely packed accordion-like morphology of MLMXene (Fig. 2(a, b)) [63]. On the other hand, etching in LiF/ HCl produces ML-MXene with less morphological changes in the starting MAX phase (Fig. 2(c)). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Ti3AlC2 show two characteristic peaks—one (1 0 4) peak at 2h 39 signifying Al atomic layers and another (0 0 2) peak at 9.5 for interlayer distance (Fig. 2(d)). After etching of the Al layers, the most intense (1 0 4) peak is largely suppressed and the other (0 0 L) peaks, corresponding to the basal planes of the MXene layers, are shifted to a lower Bragg angle. The shift is due to the expansion in interlayer spacing caused by replacing Al atomic layers with functional groups (–O–, –OH, or –F) and eventual incorporation of water and ions [76–77]. For Ti3C2Tx produced by direct HF etching, the initial (0 0 2) peak of the MAX phase is shifted to lower angles around 9.08 , indicating a larger lattice parameter (c-LP) = 19.6 Å (Fig. 2(d)) [34,76]. Meanwhile, in Ti3C2Tx produced by etching in LiF/HCl, the (0 0 2) peak is shifted to around 7.82 corresponding to a c-LP = 22.6 Å, which is larger than the c-LP of Ti3C2Tx (HF) (Fig. 2(e)). This difference is likely due to the increasing number of water layers incorporated between the nanosheets from in situ etching with a metal halide [65]. As a result, intercalation of cations, such as Li+ and water, during etching increases the spacing between MXene layers, facilitating

According to quantitative NMR experiments, there are about 3.5-fold and 2-fold more –F and –OH groups present on the surface of MXene prepared by direct HF etching compared with that in the HCl/LiF method, respectively. However, the oxygen content is about 1.5 times higher in Ti3C2Tx prepared by HCl/LiF compared to the direct HF etching method [79]. DFT Gibbs free energy (DG) calculations were consistent with NMR observations that the chemical exfoliation produces random and nonuniform distribution of surface terminal groups on MXenes. Additionally, –F terminations were more dominant than –OH and –O– terminations due to the higher electronegativity of F ions and greater associated stability to the overall structure [79].

This metastability of MXenes under ambient conditions can be a major obstacle towards their implementation for applications requiring extended lifetimes. On the other hand, this ensures the safe degradation of MXenes in the environment. Pristine DL-MXene flakes suffer from degradation by forming oxides under prolonged exposure to oxygen in presence of water, at elevated temperatures or under UV (sun) radiation in air. For instance, when a colloidal solution of DL-MXene is exposed to air, Ti3C2Tx flakes are completely oxidized within several days [80–81]. The quintessential layered structure is gradually destroyed by oxygen triggering nucleation of titanium dioxide (TiO2) crystals at the edges of MXene flakes, eventually transforming the layered Ti3C2Tx structure into TiO2 on carbon sheets. This can be observed by changes in the solution color from translucent greenish/black to cloudy white, with TiO2 precipitates [78,80]. Heuristically, higher-quality (fewer defects, larger specific surface area) large flakes of MXene have demonstrated higher environmental stability [78]. Zhang et al. studied the rate of degradation of MXene colloids in open vials at room temperature [82]. Efforts have been made to preserve the original texture and properties of MXenes and to enhance their performance in oxidizing environments through various stabilization methods. Wu et al. have stabilized MXene against structural degradation using a carbon nanoplating method [84]. New 2D hierarchical MoS2/Ti3C2-MXene@C nanohybrids were fabricated by assembling MoS2 nanoplates on carbon-stabilized Ti3C2 MXene. The synergy between Ti3C2 and MoS2 nanostructures have greatly enhanced the structural stability of the composite, with the help of carbon coating. Moreover, the capping effect and reducibility of carbon coating are believed to restrict the surface oxidation and structural degradation of MXenes during synthesis [84]. Aston et al. calculated the theoretical thermodynamic stability of 54 MXene compounds to identify more stable MXene candidates for different applications. It was concluded that oxygenterminated transition metal nitrides, such as Ti3N2O2, should be experimentally viable and Sc-based MXenes with F on the surface are expected to be highly stable due to the highest degree of thermodynamic stability as well as reasonably low exfoliation energies [86].
To summarize, the stability of MXene flakes is largely dependent on the variances in synthesis conditions, quality of the sheets, degree of exfoliation, and the proportion of surface terminations. One way to extend the stability of MXene is by proper storage in oxygen-free degassed water or in dry air. In addition, storage in a refrigerated dark environment or in dry conditions under vacuum helps to slow down the oxidation of colloidal MXene solutions. sections.heading: Water treatment applications
sections.text: MXenes integrate the advantages of adsorptive, reductive, antibacterial and metallic properties combined with high hydrophilicity, electronic conductivity, and processability. This has lead to a growing interest in utilizing MXene derivatives in water/wastewater treatment applications. Specifically, Ti3C2Tx and its composites have demonstrated efficient removal and sequestration of heavy metals, dyes, and radionuclides; while simultaneously acting as antibacterial agents for water disinfection [47,49,87]. Until now, application of MXenes in water/ wastewater treatment can be categorized into three main directions, namely: adsorbents, membranes, and electrode materials for electrochemical separation and deionization (see Table 1).

sections.heading: MXene adsorbents
sections.text:
Adsorption is a widely used water purification technique due to its ease of operation, comparatively low cost, high removal effi-
ciency, availability of various adsorbent materials and less harmful secondary products [88]. The large specific surface area and pore size distribution, chemical stability, and ability to produce the adsorbent material in industrial sized quantities are vital to assure the process is efficient and feasible for water purification [88–89]. Several nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene, zero-valent iron (ZVI), iron oxide, and chitosan have been widely employed to remove various pollutants from wastewater [18,90–93]. Due to the high specific surface area, abundant functional –OH and –O groups with tunable surface chemistry, the adsorption performance of MXenes can effectively compete with or outperform other nanomaterials. Moreover, the presence of functional groups on MXene surface not only provides sites for direct ion exchange, but also reduces some organic molecules and cations [59–60,94]. This in situ reduction ability coupled with adsorption is considered advantageous over many other nanomaterials and opens a new promising function of MXenes for unique reductive-adsorptive removal of pollutants. Due to a high negative surface charge (zeta-potential between 30 and 80 mV), MXenes have demonstrated excellent ability to spontaneously intercalate Na+, K+, NH4 +, Mg2+,

MXenes have demonstrated an ability to adsorb several heavy metals such as lead (Pb), copper (Cu), chromium (Cr) and mercury [49,59,95]. MXenes’ surface groups interact with the desired pollutant to adsorb them [49]. The thin interlayer spacing (<2Å) between MXene nanosheets leads to strong trapping of cations of radii <4.5 Å which is distinctive compared to other 2D and porous materials [58]. Intercalation of cations and/or small organic molecules may further open the interlayer spacing by increasing the c-LP for faster adsorption [31]. Likewise, the presence of hydrophilic groups and weak bonding forces in hydrated MXene can bind a greater number of water molecules, resulting in a reversible increase of the c-LP with monolayer to triple layers of water inserted between MXene nanosheets, allowing more ions to accumulate between the sheets [58].
The surface of MXenes can be tailored by functionalization, which influences its physical properties and ability to adsorb certain species. Peng et al. [96] synthesized alk-MXene (Ti3C2(OH/ ONa)xF2 x) having activated hydroxyl groups on the surface by treating Ti3C2Tx with 5% sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solution for 2 h (Fig. 4 (a, b)). The alk-MXene was used to selectively remove Pb2+, showing good average adsorption capacity and selectivity towards adsorption of Pb2+ in presence of high concentrations of competing cations like Ca2+ and Mg2+ [96]. This high removal capacity was attributed to the layered structure of alk-MXene and the presence of abundant activated Ti–OH sites, where hydroxyl and oxygen groups have formed a hexagonal hydroxyl trap for Pb2+. The negative formation energies for the adsorption of Pb2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Pd2+, and Cd2+ indicate that alk-MXene can be an excellent candidate for adsorption of toxic heavy metals as predicted via density functional theory (DFT) [97].
The ability of M2X-type MXenes to remove Pb 2+ and the role of M and X sites (where, M = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, and X is carbon or nitrogen) in Pb2+ removal was studied by DFT [94]. Among all M2X(OH)2 structures, Ti2C(OH)2 was predicted as the most promising MXene for removing heavy metals.

Adsorption behavior of Pb2+ and Cu2+ on V2C and Ti2C MXenes has been further studied by molecular dynamics (MD) simulation with a calculated theoretical adsorption capacity of 2560 mg g 1 [98].
The exterior surface groups of MXenes not only provide direct ion exchange sites, but also reduce some organic molecules and cations like Cu2+, Ag+, and Cr6+ [59–60,94]. This in situ reduction ability reveals a new promising function of MXenes for pollutant removal. For example, DL-Ti3C2Tx nanosheets exhibited efficient reductive removal of Cr6+, where the residual concentration of Cr6+ after treatment was less than 5 parts per billion (ppb) with a maximum removal capacity of 250 mg g 1 as shown in Fig. 5 (a, b) [60]. This process was able to reduce Cr6+ to Cr3+ in a single step and simultaneously remove Cr3+ from aqueous solution by adsorption. Ti3C2Tx nanosheets can also be used for the reductive removal of other oxidants, such as K3[Fe(CN)6], KMnO4 and NaAuCl4, from a variety of water/wastewater streams [60]. Similarly, surface functional groups on MXene nanosheets enabled the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu2O and CuO followed by adsorption of reduced products. In this process, DL-Ti3C2Tx demonstrated a maximum experimental removal capacity of 78.45 mg g 1 with 2.7-fold higher recyclability than that of a commercial activated carbon [59].

High removal of all hydroxylated and carbonated uranyl species was predicted due to strong bonding between uranyl ions and hydroxyl groups of V2CTx nanosheets. To summarize this section, both pristine and functionalized MXenes demonstrated efficient removal of metal ions, salts, dyes, and radionucleotides by adsorption. The successful application of MXenes as an adsorbent material is attributed to their tunable surface chemistry, availability of abundant functional groups and the capacity to respond to local electrical and chemical perturbations. MXenes can also be oxidized in situ, hence can be utilized for reductive removal of several ions. Moreover, the strong optical absorption allows MXenes and its nanocomposites to be powerful agents for the photodegradation of several contaminants including dyes followed by adsorption. In order to make further progress, efforts should be dedicated to synthesize and functionalize more types of MXenes with imparted physicochemical characteristics. For example, two new families of ordered double transition metal carbide MXenes–- M02M00C2 and M02M002C3 – where M0 and M00 are two different early transition metals, have been theoretically predicted and confirmed by the synthesis of Mo2TiC2Tx, Mo2Ti2C3Tx and Cr2TiC2Tx [37]. The restacking and small interlayer spacing of pristine MXenes are the main limitations for removing radionuclides and other pollutants with large hydrated ionic radii, limiting radionuclide adsorption. Intercalation and/or delamination of MXenes into smaller nanosheets can be one approach to increase the surface accessibility and significantly improve the adsorption capacity of adsorbates. Desalination and water treatment membranes should provide high flux, high selectivity, improved stability, and resistance to chlorine and fouling [105]. Membranes should be thin, yet mechanically stable to maximize water permeability and yield consistent salt rejection rates [5]. The high strength of 2D layers, remarkable flexibility, high surface area, and hydrophilicity render MXenes useful as water purification membranes. Like other 2Dmaterials, such as graphene, GO, and transition-metal chalcogenides, MXenes’ sieving mechanism of target molecules is governed by size exclusion through the stacked layers and interaction between the transported molecules and the charged MXene layers. 2D MXene sheets can be stacked to form thin microporous films on macroporous substrates. These films have a variable effective interlayer spacing between dried slits depending on the wetting conditions – between 2.9 Å in dry membrane (monolayer or less of water molecules) and 6.4 Å or more in wet conditions (3 layers of water and solvated ions). Narrow interlayer spacing of water-intercalated MXenes can be effective to reject small ions from water [58].
The first MXene water purification membrane was prepared by vacuum-assisted filtration (VAF) of colloidal Ti3C2Tx solution onto a hydrophilic polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) substrate with a pore size of 0.45 lm, forming a binder-free, flexible Ti3C2Tx film (Fig. 8(b)). By this simple method, MXene sheets restack themselves to form a membrane with a well-defined interlayer distance and slit-like channels to act as the separation pathway for charge and size-selective ion sieving (Fig. 8(d)) [58]. DFT calculations were used to validate the potential of Ti3C2(OH)2 MXene in water purification applications [116]. A particular focus was given to find the origin of charge selective ion sieving through stacked Ti3C2(OH)2, which was related to surface charges of the sheets [58]. Charge calculations using the density derived electrostatic and chemical charges method showed the negative charges on the surface of Ti3C2Tx (T = –F, –O–, and –OH). The results showed that the interlayer distance of bilayer MXene decreases with increasing charge state of the ions due to electrostatic interactions. In the latter work, the effect of surface functionalization of Ti3C2Tx on the selectivity of the MXene membrane towards intercalating ions such as Na+, Mg2+, and Al3+ has been predicted. The reactive force field (ReaxFF) model for Ti3C2(OH)2 MXene was used to study the theoretical dynamics of water molecules in MXene membranes using MD simulations to address the stability of these membranes hydrogenous media [117]. The calculated diffusion coefficient of water (5.33 10 10 m2 s 1) in such a confined space was in good agreement with the experimental values. The ReaxFF MD simulations also predicted that the self-diffusion coefficient of water would decrease by two orders of magnitude after the intercalation of potassium ions between the interlayer spacing, indicating enhanced operational stability of these 2D materials after the ion intercalation.
So far, the unique characteristics of MXenes, including rich chemical components, lamellar structure, ion intercalation capacity, tunable electronic conductivities, bactericidal properties, and multiple surface functionalities make them promising membrane materials. Specifically, ion intercalation into the layered Ti3C2Tx structure poses an efficient alternative towards enhanced electrochemical desalination. The majority of current research, however, has focused on the Ti3C2Tx nanosheets, and it would be beneficial to explore ion-sieving performances of other MXenes.

sections.heading: MXenes for electrochemical separation
sections.text:
Capacitive deionization (CDI) is an energy efficient method to selectively remove low concentrations of multivalent ions, comparable to brackish water, from aqueous or organic media. CDI operates by electro-sorption of ions at the electrically charged fluid–solid interface between the electrolyte and electrode [118]. The hydrophilicity, high volumetric capacitance, high electrical conductivity, tunable thicknesses and interlayer distances of MXenes may be exploited to modify ion transport and eventually be applied for CDI applications [119]. MXenes can capitalize on their outstanding pseudocapacitive properties and Faradaic ion intercalation in their layered structure to perform as energy efficient desalination of seawater or industrial wastewater; in contrast to conventional CDI and electrical double-layer capacitors [120]. In the absence of ion exchange
Please cite this article in press as: K. Rasool et al., Materials Today, (2019), https://doi.org/1
membranes, MXene can allow permselective removal of ions at high efficiency even at high molar strength [121]. The first MXene based CDI electrode was fabricated by drop-casting ML Ti3C2Tx onto both sides of a commercial porous separator and tested in a symmetric cell configuration [61]. The CDI cell demonstrated an average salt adsorption capacity of 13 ± 2 mg g 1 over 30 cycles. The same group has extended their work to present Mo1.33C MXene/CNT matrix as binder-free CDI electrode, in the absence of ion exchange membranes. CNTs were used to boost durability of the electrode and prevent restacking of the MXene sheets. The exceptional pseudocapacitive performance of Mo1.33C based CDI cell achieved a promising salt removal capacity of both anions and cations simultaneously with a charge efficiency reaching 97% [122].
In a recent study, a modified Ti3C2Tx MXene coated electrodes were assembled in a CDI cell [123]. Ar plasma treatment was used to form anatase TiO2 and an amorphous carbon layer on the Ti3C2Tx surface to enlarge the interlayer spacing of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets (increasing the c-LP from 19.4 Å to 25.30 Å). The cell was operated in batch mode, feeding saline solution continuously through the CDI cell and applying direct current voltage to investigate the desalination performance of the MXenebased electrodes (Fig. 10(a)). Electrochemical characterization of modified Ti3C2Tx electrodes is displayed in Fig. 10(b, c). The desalination performance of CDI cell was monitored by investigating maximum salt removal rate and capacity, as shown in Fig. 10(d, e). A maximum salt removal rate of 9.4 mg g 1 min 1 with an increased removal capacity of 26.8 mg g 1 was obtained for the Ar plasma modified Ti3C2Tx, higher than that of wet chemical modified electrodes. In addition, the Ti3C2Tx based CDI system showed good capacity retention for several sequences of electro-sorption and desorption.
More recently, Bao et al. used porous DL-Ti3C2Tx MXene electrode for CDI desalination [124]. In this report, a freeze-dried porous Ti3C2Tx with a large specific surface area was used to produce electrodes for CDI to purify low salinity water. Porous MXene based CDI electrodes achieved a high specific and volumetric capacitance of 156 F g 1 and 410 F cm 3, respectively. Moreover, a high electro-adsorption capacity of 45 mg g 1 was observed when an external voltage of 1.2 V was applied. Excellent CDI salt removal capacity and cycling stability over 60 cycles of the porous Ti3C2Tx electrode was attributed to the intercalation of ions into the electrode structure. In addition, higher volumetric capacitance, pore size distribution, porosity, surface area and total pore volumes of Ti3C2Tx electrodes played an important role in the performance of constructed CDI cell.
Other environmental applications of MXenes MXenes have been employed for various environmental applications beyond water/wastewater treatment. These applications can be divided into photocatalysis, sensing, electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding, and antibacterial & antibiofouling (see Table 1).

In addition to modifying surface groups, arranging their surface groups relative to the M atoms can also be advantageous to fulfill the requirements for photocatalysis application [125,129]. Since highly metallically conductive MXenes possess an intensive localized surface plasmonic resonance (LSPR) effect, MXenes have also been considered as a promising substrate for surfaceenhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) [130]. MXenes, having a bandgap between 0.92–1.75 eV, were predicted to show light absorbance at wavelengths in the range of 300 to 500 nm [128]. The structural, electronic, and optical properties of MXenes (M2CT2 where M = Ti, Zr, Hf; T = –F, –O–, and/or –OH) with different geometries were theoretically investigated for photocatalysis [128]. The M2CT2 with the functional groups located on opposing sides of the metal atoms are the most suitable for photocatalytic applications. This result suggests that Ti2CO2, Zr2CO2, and Hf2CO2 have the potential to be exploited in visiblelight driven photocatalysis [128]. Another study also found that 2D Zr2CO2 and Hf2CO2 can be used as promising photocatalytic materials for water splitting due to their remarkable anisotropic carrier mobility, strong optical absorption in both visible light and ultraviolet wavelengths, and stability in water [126]. The effect of functional groups on the photo-electrochemical properties of Sc2CT2 MXene and the possible photocatalytic activities of the differently terminated compounds were assessed via computational methods [131]. Accordingly, comparison of the photocatalytic properties of Sc2CF2, Sc2CO2, and Sc2C(OH)2 structures with similar (energetically) favorable geometries suggested that Sc2CF2 has an appropriate band structure and higher redox capability of photo-activated carriers, leading to better photocatalytic performance. TiO2/Ti3C2Tx nanocomposites have also been used for hydrogen production through photocatalytic water splitting [132]. In this nanocomposite, Ti3C2Tx acted as an electron sink to promote the separation of photo-generated charge carriers and provide a 2D platform for intimate interactions with TiO2 NPs. A 400% enhancement in the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction for the TiO2/Ti3C2Tx (5 wt%) composite was obtained over pure rutile TiO2 under visible-light irradiation.
In general, exposing the highly active facets to the photoexcitation source is considered a powerful approach to improve photocatalytic performance. It has been proven that (0 0 1) facets are the most active in TiO2 and coupling TiO2 nanosheets with other 2D materials result in enhancement of the photocatalytic activity [134–136]. A composite comprised of (0 0 1) faceted TiO2 nanosheets and layered Ti3C2Tx was synthesized and its photocatalytic performance was evaluated [133]. The highly active (0 0 1) facets of TiO2 in the composite can afford high–efficiency photogeneration of electron-hole pairs. In addition, the carrier separation is significantly promoted by a hole trapping effect by the interfacial Schottky junction, where 2D Ti3C2Tx acts as a hole reservoir. From DFT calculations, it was found that the interface formation originated from the overlapping of the Ti dorbital and the O p-orbital, as shown in Fig. 11(a, b). The work function of –OH-terminated Ti3C2Tx sheets (1.8 eV) is lower than that of TiO2 (4.924 eV for (0 0 1) surface, 6.578 eV for (1 0 1) surface), which can create a Schottky barrier through their interfaces. The photogenerated holes, as opposed to electrons, could be injected from TiO2 to –OH terminated Ti3C2. The Schottky barrier formed at the TiO2/Ti3C2Tx interface could efficiently prevent the holes from flowing back to TiO2 (Fig. 11(c, d)). In another study, the photocatalytic activity of a hybrid material composed of 2D Ti3C2Tx and Ti

Moreover, Ti3C2Tx has been used as a highly active co-catalyst on metal sulfide photo-absorbers towards visible–light photocatalytic hydrogen production [138]. The –F terminations on Ti3C2Tx were replaced by –O/–OH terminations by hydrothermal reaction and the resulting structure coupled with cadmium sulfide (CdS) to form a CdS/Ti3C2Tx nanocomposite. This composite displayed a high photocatalytic hydrogen production activity of 14342 mmol h 1 g 1 in visible–light and apparent quantum efficiency of 40.1% at 420 nm. The work towards the development of MXene-based nano-architectures provides a basic understanding about how to design a well-contacted heterojunction interface between MXene and the other NPs to achieve superior photoredox efficiency in photocatalysis and energy conversion applications. However, it is also important to note that MXenes, including Ti3C2Tx, absorb light in both UV and visible ranges, showing plasmon resonance peaks in visible or IR range [139]. Thereby, they can be efficient in light-to-heat conversion. Thus, some of the effects assigned to photo-catalysis may result from heating and thermal acceleration of chemical reactions according to Arrhenius law.

The ability to tune the surface terminations of MXenes can also be useful for various sensing applications. MXene-based gas sensors utilize the changes in MXene conductivity during gas molecule attachment (adsorption or intercalation). Based on DFT calculations, Ti2CTx monolayer with oxygen terminations was preferentially selective towards ammonia (NH3) relative to other gas molecules. The results revealed that NH3 molecules could be strongly adsorbed onto oxygen-terminated M2CTx family of MXenes, leading to charge transfer. Subsequent NH3 desorption can be achieved upon modifying the charge state on the system by tuning the electrons injected into M2CTx [140]. The ability of MXenes to detect NH3 was also confirmed experimentally by Lee et al. [141]. The Ti3C2Tx nanosheets were integrated onto flexible polyimide films and the sensor was found to have a significant response to NH3 [141]. In addition, the possibility of Ti3C2Tx films as metallic channels for chemiresistive gas sensors have been evaluated, exhibiting a low detection limit of 50–100 ppb for volatile organic compound (VOC) gases at room temperature. The enhanced performance was attributed to high metallic conductivity for low noise and a fully functionalized surface of MXene, which results in a strong signal. Antibacterial properties of MXene and anti-biofouling applications Nanomaterials with bactericidal characteristics could be efficiently employed for water/wastewater treatment, disinfection, anti-biofouling coatings, and other environmental remediation processes. Various characteristic properties of MXenes including their electronic conductivity, hydrophilicity, nanometer sharp edges, and production of oxidative stress render MXenes as potential candidates to have bactericidal effects. To date, only a few studies have investigated the antibacterial properties of MXenes. The antibacterial characteristics of Ti3C2Tx were studied against Escherichia coli (E. coli) and Bacillus subtilis (B. subtilis) as model Gram (+) and Gram ( ) bacteria, respectively, in aqueous suspension [62,159]. Ti3C2Tx nanosheets showed higher activity against B. subtilis compared to E. coli at low Ti3C2Tx concentrations. E. coli and B. subtilis cells showed significant cell deformation, membrane damage and cytoplasmic leakage after exposure to Ti3C2Tx nanosheets (Fig. 13(a–c)). Moreover, Ti3C2Tx exhibited concentration-dependent bactericidal properties with more than 99% cell inhibition against both bacterial strains at 200 mg mL 1 of Ti3C2Tx (Fig. 13(d, e)). Reaction with Ti3C2Tx also resulted in lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) release and loss of glutathione by bacteria, depicting oxidative stress mediated by Ti3C2Tx, as shown in Fig. 13(f, g). Consequently, the antibacterial activity of layered Ti2CTx and Ti3C2Tx aqueous dispersions was studied against E. coli, B. subtilis, S. aureus and Sarcina bacterial strains [160–161]. It was found that Ti2CTx has insignificant antibacterial activity against Gram (+) Bacillus sp., S. aureus and Sarcina and Gram ( ) E. coli bacteria. sections.heading: Toxicity and environmental impact
sections.text:
With the fast utilization of MXenes in various applications, the toxicity and life cycle analysis of waste fromMXenes and MXene derivatives in the ecosystem should be addressed. Given the versatile chemistry, structure, and properties of MXenes, it is sensible to evaluate the prospective hazards linked with its use and environmental exposure. Like many other nanoscale materials, the main exposure routes could be through the respiratory system, gastrointestinal system, and skin. The release of MXenes nanomaterials into the environment will likely impact living organisms even at the lowest trophic levels such as bacteria. Certainly, several nanomaterials including graphene [173], CNTs [174] and metallic NPs [175] have already been confirmed toxic to living organisms; therefore, we should consider the potential toxicity of 2D MXenes materials.

Significant in vitro cytotoxicity of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets was reported against cancerous and normal cells (Fig. 15(e, f)) [177]. Toxicity was assigned to oxidative stress, due to the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS). Ti3C2Tx has also been studied for urea adsorption without inducing cell apoptosis. In this study, there was no reduction found in the metabolizing cell fraction, indicating non-toxicity and biocompatibility of Ti3C2Tx [178]. Moreover, Ti3C2Tx was implemented into neuroelectronic devices with high-resolution neural recording performance, showing neuronal biocompatibility without adverse effects on neuron growth [179]. Surface chemistry is an important factor which can affect the potential cytotoxicity, depending on the type of M element, the etching and delamination conditions, and post-synthesis treatment and storage [35]. Following this study, other research groups have investigated the effect of surface modification on toxicity and biocompatibility of different MXene nanostructures [127,180–181]. For instance, development of a fluorine-free method for MXene preparation could result in decreased cytotoxicity and improved biocompatibility. Biocompatibility of Ti3C2Tx MXene quantum dots (QDs) prepared by direct ultra-sonication of MAX phase was studied by a colorimetric MTT cytotoxicity assay, showing low cytotoxicity at 100 lg mL 1 concentration without any abnormal changes in mouse behavior, body weight, and diet [182]. Improving MXene biocompatibility was attempted in another study where a multifunctional nano-platform was produced by surface modification of MXene with doxorubicin (DOX) and hyaluronic acid (HA) [182].
Few other reports have attempted to investigate the biocompatibility of MXene nanocomposites. A MnOx/Ti3C2Tx MXene nanocomposite did not show any significant cytotoxicity even at the higher concentrations of 160 lg mL 1 for 48 h incubation, indicating high biocompatibility of the MnOx/Ti3C2Tx-SP composite nanosheets [183]. Also, MnOx/Ta4C3Tx nanocomposite exhibited negligible cytotoxicity to mouse 4T1 cells for in vitro assays [184]. Ultrathin 2D niobium carbide (Nb2CTx) MXene was explored as a phototherapeutic agent for treatment of mouse tumors without obvious toxicity [127]. Nb2CTx was modified with polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) to increase the biocompatibility of the composite. Nb2CTx/PVP did not exhibit any significant renal and hepatic toxicity in mice.
Although several studies demonstrated biocompatibility or non-acute toxicity of different MXenes, Ti3C2Tx has shown the ability to pass through bacterial membranes [62]; therefore, it may have potential to distress the physiology of any cell in the body. Considering the fast development and growing number of MXene nanomaterials, continuous screening of toxicity and environmental impact of MXenes, with various structure (M2X, M3X2, and M4X3), surface chemistries, particle size and concentration of defects is encouraged.

sections.heading: Conclusions and outlook
sections.text:
The various MXenes are amid the most promising 2D nanomaterials being developed for different applications, due to their unique properties and tunable structure and composition. MXenes are being widely explored for water/wastewater purification and environmental remediation applications, including water treatment/desalination membranes, adsorbents, catalytic substrates, and bactericidal agents. Recent efforts have been dedicated to improving the stability, biocompatibility, and recyclability of MXenes in aqueous systems and ambient air conditions to maximize their effectiveness in water purification applications. MXene derivatives can be developed by tuning and controlling the surface chemistry, including functionalization and controlled oxidation. Similarly, several MXene-based composites with polymeric matrices (such as PVA, PVDF, PEI, PDMS, PES, etc.) have been fabricated to overcome some limitations of pristine MXenes like aggregation and long-term stability. It is still important to develop new MXene structures that are more environmentally stable in applications where contact with water is inevitable. Since numerous MXenes, in addition to >30 already available, have been predicted theoretically, there is potential for more MXenes to emerge and become available for water treatment and many other environmental applications.
Currently, Ti3C2Tx is the most studied member of the MXene family in water purification and environmental remediation applications. It has been widely used as an adsorbent and for the reductive removal of metal ions from water and photodegradation of dyes. Still, it is much less studied compared to graphene and other 2D materials. Ti2CTx and Ti3NC produce the same non-toxic decomposition products as Ti3C2Tx and should receive particular attention. In addition, the naturally abundant elements that make-up many MXenes may be advantageous for cost-sensitive environmental applications. More investigations are also required to improve stability and achieve recyclability of MXene adsorbents, so that consistent performance is achieved even after repeated use. More studies are needed to bridge the gap between the newly predicted and experimentally available MXenes with the hope of identifying candidate materials with enhanced thermal, electrical, and catalytic properties that are more suitable for water treatment and environmental remediation. Experimental verification of theoretical predictions is an important task that may facilitate the development of materials with improved photocatalytic, electrocatalytic and other useful properties.
MXenes have been fabricated into membranes for desalination and water treatment. With the right tuning of surface chemistry, MXene membranes can achieve superior selectivity towards ion separation through both size and charge sieving mechanisms along with ultrafast water transport. Particularly, the hydrophilicity, high volumetric capacitance, high electrical conductivity, tunable thicknesses and interlayer distances of MXenes may be exploited in voltage-gated ion transport and eventually be applied for CDI applications. The interlayer spacing between the stacked sheets plays a key role in determining the separation efficiency, flow rate and selectivity of lamellar MXene membranes. MXene membranes, similar to other 2D nanomaterials, can suffer from membrane swelling in aqueous

While MXenes have shown promising results in photocatalysis, they have few drawbacks like poor photon absorption and high rate of charge carrier recombination, which could be improved by designing well-contacted heterojunction interfaces between MXene and other NPs. New nano-architectures of MXene with higher light harvesting ability (e.g., Ti3C2Tx-TiO2) can satisfy the quantum efficiency and enhance carrier separation, achieving superior photo-redox efficiency in photocatalysis and energy conversion applications. Other MXene-oxide systems (ZrO2 on Zr-MXenes, Nb2O5 of Nb-MXenes, MoO3 on MoMXenes, etc.) should also be explored. Those oxides can either be anchored on MXenes can be produced in situ by partial oxidation of MXenes.
CertainMXenes exhibit antibacterial activity against somebacteria, demonstrating potential use in water disinfection and antibiofouling membranes. Yet, more work is still required to fully understand the bactericidal mechanisms of MXenes. Preliminary studies demonstrated biocompatibility or non-acute toxicity of MXenes even at high concentrations, while some other reports noted some effects on the viability of both normal and cancerous cells exposed toMXene. It becomes important to domore comprehensive investigations on the potential hazards linked with MXenes, as thematerials not only becomewidely studied, but also areworking their way up to commercial products. Also doing a full life-cycle analysis and determining the effects on agriculture, water quality, and aquatic life is necessary. The known hazards of other nanomaterials on living organisms, suggests that more research is needed to safely design, use, and dispose of MXenecontaining products to avoid health and environmental hazards. This might be especially critical for MXenes containing transition metals beyondbenign titanium.Understanding toxicity and environmental impact of MXenes would considerably expand the range of their applications in environmental remediation and pave a way for the construction of novel MXenes composites satisfying environmental safety requirements.
MXenes are still produced at the lab scale in ten to hundred gram quantities. Therefore, it is very difficult to determine if and when they will become competitive in cost with graphene and other 2D materials. However, since Ti3C2, Ti3CN, Ti2C and several other MXenes consist of abundant elements, they can potentially be produced in large volume at a moderate price, comparable to that of bulk metal carbides.

metadata.abstractText: The discovery of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides and nitrides (MXenes) in 2011 has expanded the pool of nanomaterials available for a variety of applications. Characteristic properties of MXenes, such as high conductivity, hydrophilicity, and catalytic activity have led to a growing research interest for their use in environmental remediation and water treatment applications. This review summarizes recent advances in the synthesis and applications of MXenes as adsorbents, desalination membranes, electrodes for electrochemical deionization, and catalytic or antibacterial agents for water purification and other environmental remediation processes. The overview also features discussions on the computational attempts, biocompatibility, and environmental impact in the exploration of MXenes for water applications, highlighting the challenges and opportunities of these advanced 2D materials.
